    yspec

    STATUS: development

    2019-01-26

    yspec.Rmd

    About

    The yspec package will read you data specification file when it is written in a specific yaml format.

    For each data set in your project that needs documentation, create a yaml file that lists the columns in the data set along with details about the data in that column. This yaml file can be loaded into your R session into an object that you can work with. This is referred to as a spec object. The term spec refers to a single documented data object / data file.

    Once all of your data sets have been documented with their own yaml file, you can create another object called a yproj objects. This is used to template the rendering of a single integrated data definitions file for your entire project.

    Keep reading the vignette to see how it works.

    library(yspec)

    Example spec file

    An example specification file looks like:

    specfile <- yspec::file_spec_ex()

cat(readLines(specfile)[1:29], sep = "\n")
      SETUP__:
    projectnumber: MRG123
    sponsor: demo
    description: an example data set
    primary_key: [ID,EVID,SEQ]
    lookup_file: [_yspec_lookup.yml]
    use_internal_db: true
    data_stem: example_data_set
  C:
    type: character
    long: commented rows
    values: [".",C]
    lookup: true
  USUBJID:
    type: character
    long: universal subject identifier
  ID:
    long: NONMEM ID number
  EVID: !look
  MDV: !look
  SEQ:
    long: record type indicators
    values: {concentration: 1, response: 2, other: 3}
  AMT:
    about: [amount, mg]
    long: dose amount
    range: [0,1000]
  II:
    about: [II, hours]

    Once the data specification yaml file is written, it can be loaded in R

    spec <- ys_load(specfile)

spec
       name    c d unit          short                         source           
   C       + - .             commented row indicator       _yspec_lookup.yml
   USUBJID + - .             USUBJID                       .                
   ID      - - .             ID                            .                
   EVID    - - .             event ID                      _yspec_lookup.yml
   MDV     - - .             MDV                           _yspec_lookup.yml
   SEQ     - + .             SEQ                           .                
   AMT     - - mg            amount                        .                
   II      - - hours         II                            .                
   CMT     - - .             Compartment                   .                
   TAFD    - - hours         TAFD                          .                
   WT      - - kg            Weight                        .                
   EGFR    - - ml/min/1.73m2 eGFR                          _yspec_lookup.yml
   STUDY   + + .             Study                         .                
   SEX     - + .             SEX                           _yspec_lookup.yml
   BQL     - + .             below limit of quantification .                
   DV      - - ng/mL         DV                            .                
   DV2     - - .             DV2                           .                
   HAIR    + + .             HAIR                          .                
   CLCR    - - ml/min        creatinine clearance          .                
   ALB     - - g/dL          adjusted albumin              _yspec_lookup.yml

    Data from specific columns can be printed

    spec$WT
       name  value    
   col   WT       
   type  numeric  
   short Weight   
   unit  kg       
   range 40 to 100

    or summarized

    summary(spec, WT, DV, EGFR)
            name c d          unit                         short
  1        C + -             .       commented row indicator
  2  USUBJID + -             .                       USUBJID
  3       ID - -             .                            ID
  4     EVID - -             .                      event ID

  6      SEQ - +             .                           SEQ
  7      AMT - -            mg                        amount
  8       II - -         hours                            II
  9      CMT - -             .                   Compartment
  10    TAFD - -         hours                          TAFD
  11      WT - -            kg                        Weight
  12    EGFR - - ml/min/1.73m2                          eGFR
  13   STUDY + +             .                         Study
  14     SEX - +             .                           SEX
  15     BQL - +             . below limit of quantification
  16      DV - -         ng/mL                            DV
  17     DV2 - -             .                           DV2
  18    HAIR + +             .                          HAIR
  19    CLCR - -        ml/min          creatinine clearance
  20     ALB - -          g/dL              adjusted albumin
                source
  1  _yspec_lookup.yml
  2                  .
  3                  .
  4  _yspec_lookup.yml
  5  _yspec_lookup.yml
  6                  .

  18                 .
  19                 .
  20 _yspec_lookup.yml

    Check a data set against the spec

    Use the ys_check() function, with the data frame as the first argument and the spec object as the second argument

    sp <- ys_load(ys_help$file())

data <- readr::read_csv(ys_help$csv(), na = '.')
    ## Parsed with column specification:
## cols(
##   .default = col_double(),
##   C = col_logical(),
##   RF = col_character()
## )
    ## See spec(...) for full column specifications.
    ys_check(data,sp)
    ## The data set passed all checks.

    Example to render spec

    The specification object can be rendered to a specification file with the ys_document function

    ys_document(spec, stem = "working_document")

    With output here.

    ys_document will pass along arguments to rmarkdown::render so that you can control those aspects of how the document is rendered. You can also create custom output formats to get the data table to render in the way that you like.

    Example project object

    To create an project-wide listing of documented data sets, we create a yproj or project object. We create this from the spec objects that we read about in the previous section. Letâ€™s load another object to use along with the object loaded in the previous section.

    pdspec <- load_spec_ex("DEM104101F_PKPD.yml")

    Now, we have two objects to work with:

    head(spec)
    ##       name c d  unit                   short            source
## 1        C + -     . commented row indicator _yspec_lookup.yml
## 2  USUBJID + -     .                 USUBJID                 .
## 3       ID - -     .                      ID                 .
## 4     EVID - -     .                event ID _yspec_lookup.yml
## 5      MDV - -     .                     MDV _yspec_lookup.yml
## 6      SEQ - +     .                     SEQ                 .
## 7      AMT - -    mg                  amount                 .
## 8       II - - hours                      II                 .
## 9      CMT - -     .             Compartment                 .
## 10    TAFD - - hours                    TAFD                 .
    head(pdspec)
    ##    name c d           unit       short source
## 1     C + -              .           C      .
## 2   MDV - -              .         MDV      .
## 3   SEQ - +              .         SEQ      .
## 4   AMT - -             mg         AMT      .
## 5    II - -          hours          II      .
## 6   CMT - -              . Compartment      .
## 7  TAFD - -          hours        TAFD      .
## 8    WT - -             kg      Weight      .
## 9  EGFR - - ml/min/1.73 m2        eGFR      .
## 10  SEX - +              .         SEX      .

    We can create a project object from both objects

    proj <- ys_project(spec,pdspec)

proj
    ## projectnumber:  MRG123 
## sponsor:        demo 
## --------------------------------------------
## datafiles: 
##  name            description                       data_stem       
##  spec            an example data set               example_data_set
##  DEM104101F_PKPD Population PKPD analysis data set DEM104101F_PKPD

    Render a project file

    Working document

    To render the project file weâ€™ll use the same ys_document() function.
    This time, weâ€™ll add some extra (optional) arguments that will help us get the document to look the way we want:

    ys_document(
  proj, 
  stem = "project_document", 
  build_dir = mrgtemplate(),
  author = "Michelle Johnson", 
  title = "Analysis data specification"
)

    With output here.

    Using the build_dir argument gets us the document rendered with Metrum Research Group branding. Also, author and title are passed into the configuration fields for this document.

    Regulatory document

    To get a document that is formatted according to FDA requirements, use:

    ys_document(
  proj, 
  type = "regulatory",
  stem = "fda_document", 
  build_dir = mrgtemplate(),
  author = "Michelle Johnson", 
  title = "Analysis data specification"
)

    With output here.
